items.title: Spotlight on SIG Architecture: API Governance

subprojects, and we will be covering <a href="https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/sig-architecture/README.md#architecture-and-api-governance-1">SIG Architecture: API
Governanc
items.reason: Kubernetes SIG Architecture API Governance is a core governance topic for the Kubernetes ecosystem and has no existing coverage in the wiki.

items.title: Gordon: Docker’s AI Agent Just Got an Update
items.summary: AI agents are moving from demos to daily workflows. They write code, run commands, and complete multi-step tasks without constant hand-holding. But general-purpose agents don't know Docker. They don't understand your containers, your images, or your specific setup. Gordon does. Just run docker ai in
items.reason: Docker’s AI agent “Gordon” introduces a new developer‑assistant feature; the wiki currently lacks any article on Docker‑specific AI agents.

items.title: Run OpenClaw Securely in Docker Sandboxes
items.summary: Docker Sandboxes is a new primitive in the Docker's ecosystem that allows you to run AI agents or any other workloads in isolated micro VMs. It provides strong isolation, convenient developer experience and a strong security boundary with a network proxy configurable to deny agents connecting to arb
items.reason: Docker Sandboxes (micro‑VM isolation) is a novel security primitive relevant to container security and AI workloads, not yet documented.

items.title: State of Agentic AI Report: Key Findings
items.summary: Based on Docker’s State of Agentic AI report, a global survey of more than 800 developers, platform engineers, and technology decision-makers, this blog summarizes key findings of what's really happening as agentic AI scales within organizations. Drawing on insights from decision-makers and purchase
items.reason: The State of Agentic AI report provides industry‑wide insights that are valuable for a technology wiki but are not covered elsewhere.

items.title: How Medplum Secured Their Healthcare Platform with Docker Hardened Images (DHI)
items.summary: Special thanks to Cody Ebberson and the Medplum team for their open-source contribution and for sharing their migration experience with the community. A real-world example of migrating a HIPAA-compliant EHR platform to DHI with minimal code changes. Healthcare software runs on trust. When patient da
items.reason: A concrete case study of Docker Hardened Images for a HIPAA‑compliant platform is useful for security and compliance sections, yet no such case study exists in the wiki.

items.title: The Multi-Model Database for AI Agents: Deploy SurrealDB with Docker Extension
items.summary: When it comes to building dynamic and real-work solutions, developers need to stitch multiple databases (relational, document, graph, vector, time-series, search) together and build complex API layers to integrate them. This generates significant complexity, cost, and operational risk, and reduces s
items.reason: SurrealDB integration via Docker Extension addresses multi‑model database deployment for AI agents, a topic not yet covered.

items.title: How AI is reshaping developer choice (and Octoverse data proves it)
items.summary:
AI is rewiring developer preferences through convenience loops. Octoverse 2025 reveals how AI compatibility is becoming the new standard for technology choice.
The post How AI is reshaping developer choice (and Octoverse data proves it) appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: GitHub’s analysis of AI’s impact on developer choice is a high‑level trend that should be documented for the developer‑tools section.

items.title: What to expect for open source in 2026
items.summary:
Let’s dig into the 2025’s open source data on GitHub to see what we can learn about the future.
The post What to expect for open source in 2026 appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: Predictions for open‑source in 2026 based on GitHub data are relevant for future‑looking wiki content and currently missing.

items.title: Securing the AI software supply chain: Security results across 67 open source projects
items.summary:
Learn how The GitHub Secure Open Source Fund helped 67 critical AI‑stack projects accelerate fixes, strengthen ecosystems, and advance open source resilience.
The post Securing the AI software supply chain: Security results across 67 open source projects appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: Security of the AI software supply chain is a critical emerging topic; the wiki has no dedicated article on this GitHub initiative.

items.title: Automate repository tasks with GitHub Agentic Workflows
items.summary:
Discover GitHub Agentic Workflows, now in technical preview. Build automations using coding agents in GitHub Actions to handle triage, documentation, code quality, and more.
The post Automate repository tasks with GitHub Agentic Workflows   appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: GitHub Agentic Workflows introduce a new automation paradigm that warrants its own documentation.

items.title: Welcome to the Eternal September of open source. Here’s what we plan to do for maintainers.
items.summary:
Open source is hitting an “Eternal September.” As contribution friction drops, maintainers are adapting with new trust signals, triage approaches, and community-led solutions.
The post Welcome to the Eternal September of open source. Here’s what we plan to do for maintainers. appeared first on
items.reason: The “Eternal September” commentary on open‑source maintainer challenges is relevant for community‑management content but not yet covered.
